data.title: CLEARY: Tracking down Ottawa's current hoops stars
data.meta_description: When power forward Aaron Doornekamp patrolled the floor for the Carleton University Ravens men’s basketball team, he was one of the pillars of that edition of that …
data.text:
Article content

When power forward Aaron Doornekamp patrolled the floor for the Carleton University Ravens men’s basketball team, he was one of the pillars of that edition of that dynamic dynasty.

Article content

A driving force behind four Canadian intercollegiate men’s basketball championships in his five years, Doornekamp was the MVP at the 2007 Final 8, the 2008 national player of the year and a two-time, first-team All-Canadian.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

CLEARY: Tracking down Ottawa's current hoops stars Back to video

Rather impressive, you’d think. But what did it mean in terms of catching the eye of the NBA? A big zero.

“I had no reason to be looking at the draft. They only had two rounds (60 players),” said an honest Doornekamp, who did have his sights set on playing pro ball since the day he entered Carleton in 2004.

Ottawa’s Kim Pierre-Louis totally understands Doornekamp’s thinking. After graduating as an athlete scholarship student from the University of Massachusetts, she was bypassed in the WNBA draft, but also dreamed of playing professionally.

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Instead of having NBA or WNBA initials after their names, Doornekamp and Pierre-Louis have found hoop happiness playing the pro game in Europe. And they have plenty of company from Ottawa, enough to fill two quality teams.

There are as many as 23 male and female players from or with connections to Ottawa playing for professional teams in the United States, Russia, Italy, Spain, Germany, Austria, Slovakia, The Netherlands, Hungary, Brazil and Canada.

“Our (national senior and youth) programs are ranked fifth in the world and that means we’re producing good quality players,” said Andy Sparks, the University of Ottawa Gee-Gees women’s head coach. “They’ve come from universities where they’re grounded kids overall and relatively mature … and no problems when they go over.”

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

One moment they’re shooting the lights out at the Ravens’ Nest, Montpetit Hall or another university gym and the next moment they’re gone. But where did they go? Are they still playing ball? Some players will pop up on the media alert radar playing for a Canadian team at an international tournament, but what club team is paying for their talents?

When Doornekamp, 33, left Carleton in 2009, he hired an agent, but all was quiet. But Doornekamp changed that during a national team tour in Italy. He made an impression and signed with Pasta Reggia JuveCaserta for one year and then two more years.

What Doornekamp had going for him was what he learned during his five years with Carleton head coach Dave Smart, who has emerged as an elite national- and international-level coach.

Advertisement 5

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

“I was lucky to be at Carleton. We played and developed the right way. Under Dave, you learned how to pass and that’s such an under-rated skill. But that translates well in Europe,” he added.

“I did shoot well at Carleton but there’s a big difference shooting at university and playing pro. The (pro) game’s a lot faster. Every year you’re adjusting. The biggest thing for me is shooting greater than 40% for three-point shots. The last five years I’ve stayed above that mark.”

Pierre-Louis, 25, had two first-year pro offers for 2015-16 and elected to play for Sepsi Sic in Romania, where she started all 27 games and averaged 10 points, 5.4 rebounds and 14.5 minutes a game. She helped Sepsi Sic win the Romanian league’s regular season and playoff titles (before sold-out home crowds) as well as the Romanian Cup.

Advertisement 6

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

“It was a great experience. Everyday practice was a dogfight, insane,” she said in an interview. “They were high-level players. It was a total learning experience.”

In Doornekamp’s first year as a pro, JuveCaserta unexpectedly overachieved in 2009-10. But the next two years were great disappointments and Doornekamp had to go to court to get his salary from the disgruntled owner.

An injury kept Doornekamp off the court in 2012-13. After playing the next year in Germany for Basketball Lowen Braunschweig, he spent the next two years with Fraport Skyliners, which won FIBA’s third-tier Europa Cup in 2015-16.

For 2016-17, he headed to Spain’s top league, where he averaged 11.5 points and 4.3 rebounds in 25.9 minutes a game for Iberostar Tenerife, which captured the Champions League season. Doornekamp also was named to the league’s Star Lineup Best Team.

Advertisement 7

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Doornekamp then signed a two-year contract with Valencia Basket last season, where he started 37 of 68 games, and averaged 21 minutes, 6.2 points, and 3.4 rebounds a game.

While he found his entry into the pro experience “a bit of an eye-opener,” Doornekamp has enjoyed it overall, receiving some guidance from his older brother Nate, who played three years in Germany.

Playing for Valencia, which is owned by Spanish supermarket chain (Mercadona) billionaire Juan Roig Alfonsa, he has a six-figure, tax-free salary, a vehicle and free accommodation.

“I essentially pay for food,” said Doornekamp, who is married with two children and can ride his bike or walk to practice.

“Where we are now, I like it. I’d like to stay in Valencia as long as they let me. It’s a great club, an unbelievable city and being here has definitely outdone my expectations.”

Advertisement 8

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Pierre-Louis would second that statement.

At the end of her opening season in Romania, Pierre-Louis received an offer to become “the” player for TH Wohnbau Angels Nordiingen of Donau-Ries in Germany’s top league. It was too hard to resist.

“I had an opportunity for more playing time and money,” said Pierre-Louis, who was the All-German division one centre of the year last season, and a multiple all-star for the past two seasons.

Pierre-Louis took another step up the ladder for 2018-19, signing with and starting for defending division one German champion Gruener Stern Keltern.

“It’s very exciting to play for this team. We’ll be playing against (elite) EuroCup players . . . who I have watched for so long,” said Pierre-Louis, who earns about $40,000 a year with all expenses paid plus a car and accommodation.

Advertisement 9

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

“It’s very stimulating year after year. I get to travel and play a game I love. It’s cool. I wouldn’t want to be at a desk for seven hours a day. I haven’t got that job yet and I hope I can hold off as long as my legs hold out.”

AROUND THE WORLD

Olivier Hanlan

From Gatineau, played at Boston College, point guard, playing for Telekom Baskets in elite German league … Signed with NBA’s San Antonio Spurs on Sept. 20, but placed on waivers Sept. 23 and was a free agent Sept. 25 … Won 2017-18 NBA G League championship with Austin Spurs … Selected in 2015 NBA draft by Utah, traded to San Antonio 2016 … Played for Zalgiris Kaunas, winning Lithuanian league title in 2015-16.

Phil Scrubb

From Richmond, B.C., played at Carleton University, shooting guard, joined Zenit Saint Petersburg, No. 3 team in Russia’s VTB United League last season, for 2018-19 season … Top scorer in premier German league in 2017-18 for Fraport Skyliners, averaging 18.3 points a game … Undrafted, but has played in NBA’s Summer League for Washington, Toronto and Memphis.

Advertisement 10

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Thomas Scrubb

From Richmond, B.C., played at Carleton, forward, signed with Pallacanestro Varese of Italian Series A league … Averaged 9.5 points, 4.6 rebounds a game last year for Sidigas Avelino (Italy) … Named top forward in 2015-16 as a rookie for Joensuun Kataja in Finland.

Johnny Berhanemeskel

From Ottawa, played at University of Ottawa, shooting guard, returns to Spain to play top division with Tecnyconta Zaragoza; was second-team all-star in Spanish second division in 2016-17 for Saenz Horeca Araberri, averaging 18.9 points a game; 2015-16 All-Baltic league import player of the year for Estonia’s Tallinna Ulikool/Kalev.

Rashida Timbilla

From Ottawa, played at University of Massachusetts, forward, replaces Pierre-Louis in starting five for Xcyde Angels of Donau-Ries (renamed), after being second-best rebounder, 13.6 a game, and added 12.1 points a game for Visby in Sweden.

Advertisement 11

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Heather Lindsay

From Ottawa, played at Carleton, forward, Carleton’s all-team leading scorer and a national champion in 2017-18 makes pro debut with SG BBZ Opladen in Germany’s second division.

Caleb Agada

From Burlington, Ont., played at Ottawa, guard, the 2016 Canadian university men’s defensive player of the year has moved up to Spain’s first division with Nelilla Baloncesto … Started 38 of 42 games last season, averaging 25.0 minutes, 14.4 points for second division CB Prat Juventut.

Hannah Sunley-Paisley

From Ottawa, played at Ottawa, centre, 2012 national university women’s player of the year starts third year in France with third-tier ASA Sceaux, after playing for Saint Paul Reze last season, averaging 29.8 minutes, 8.3 points, 5.1 rebounds a game;

Advertisement 12

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Jean Emmanuel Pierre-Charles

From Ottawa, played at Carleton/Ottawa, forward, silver medallist for Canada at the 2018 Commonwealth Games, starts pro career with division two Saenz Horeca Araberri in Spain.

Cameron Smythe

From Vancouver, played at Carleton, forward/centre, strong outside shooter makes pro debut with Oberwart Gunners in Austria.

Audrey-Ann Caron-Goudreau

From Gatineau, played at Texas, power forward, rookie with Eisvogel USC Freiburg in Germany’s elite women’s league … Started 23 games for Texas in 2017-18 before season-ending wrist injury, averaged 6.0 points and 5.0 rebounds a game.

Jahenns Manigat

JAHENNS MANIGAT, Ottawa, Creighton University, guard, enters fifth European season with Debreceni Egyetem of Hungary; averaged 10.7 points a game with teams in Lithuania and Germany in 2017-18.

Advertisement 13

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Connor Wood

From Guelph, Ont., played at Carleton, guard, after playing last season with the National Basketball League of Canada’s Niagara River Lions, averaging 9.3 points a game in 44 appearances, the 2017 national men’s university player of the year has joined Paderborn Baskets in Germany’s second tier.

Joe Rocca

From Sarnia, Ont., played at Carleton, guard, after averaging 5.7 points a game for Niagara River last season, he signed with BK Spisska Nova Ves in the Slovakian league for the 2018-19 campaign.

Adam Presutti

From Oakville, Ont., played at Ottawa, guard, starts second season as one of five Canadians on BK Spisska Nova Ves … In seven games last season averaged 14.9 minutes, 6.3 points a game.

Shayok Shayok

Advertisement 14

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

From Ottawa, played at University of Missouri-Kansas City, forward, played for UniFacisa (9-7) this year in the Brazilian league, but lost in the quarterfinals.

Kevin Bercy

From Kanata, St. Francis Xavier University, forward, making pro debut with Zornotza Saskkibaloi Taldea in Spain’s second division … Was 2016-17 Atlantic University Sport MVP, averaging 19.8 points, 11.3 rebounds a game.

Kaza Kajami-Keane

From Ajax, Ont., played at Carleton, guard, played 43 games for Raptors 905 in the NBA’s G League in 2017-18, averaging 19.8 minutes, 6.6 points, 4.5 assists a game … Playing for Landstede Zwolle in The Netherlands in 2018-19.

Michael Fraser

From Ottawa, played at Oklahoma Baptist University, centre, dependable scorer and rebounder, playing with Bakery Piacentina of Italian Serie A2, giving him a career 11 different teams in nine countries over nine seasons.

In the National Basketball League of Canada

Guillaume Payen-Boucard, from Montreal, played at Carleton, guard, a standout for Niagara River in 2017-18, averaging 14.0 points, 7.6 rebounds a game; playing for St. John’s Edge in 2018-19 … Kevin Zabo, Gatineau, Kent State University, guard, a strong all-around contributor in his 2017-18 senior year, signed first pro contract with St. John’s Edge for 2018-19.
